SENT.plain: We reviewed the efficacy of CSF diversion for pseudotumor cerebri (PTC) in patients from six different institutions
Thirty-seven patients underwent a total of 73 lumboperitoneal shunts and nine ventricular shunts
Only 14 patients remained "cured" after a single surgical procedure
The average time between shunt insertion and shunt replacement was 9 months, although 64% of shunts lasted less than 6 months
Shunt failure (55%) and low-pressure headaches (21%) were the most common causes for reoperation
The vision of most patients improved (13) or stabilized (13) postoperatively
However, three who had initially improved subsequently lost vision
Six had a postoperative decrease in vision
Two patients improved in one eye but worsened postoperatively in the other
Four lost vision despite apparently adequate shunt function
Shunt failure with relapse of PTC occurred as late as 7 years after insertion
CSF diversion procedures have a significant failure rate as well as a high frequency of side effects
